importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of article publication, marking the reporting of the election results and the political shift in Bolivia.
Date of the initial election that led to the runoff between Rodrigo Paz and Jorge Quiroga, showing the political context preceding the final vote.
Date when Rodrigo Paz is set to take office as president, marking the beginning of his administration and the implementation of new policies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2023 to 2025 marks the ongoing economic crisis in Bolivia, including severe dollar shortages, inflation, and fuel shortages, which shaped public dissatisfaction and electoral dynamics.

keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator, won the Bolivian presidential election with 54.5% of the vote, defeating former right-wing president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45.5%.
Paz’s victory ends 20 years of rule by the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party, marking a significant political transformation.
Paz plans to dismantle Bolivia’s fixed exchange rate, end fuel subsidies, and reduce public investment, signaling a shift from the MAS economic model.
Bolivia faces a severe economic crisis characterized by high inflation (23% year-on-year), fuel shortages, and a critical shortage of U.S. dollars.
Rodrigo Paz’s running mate, ex-police Capt. Edman Lara, rose to prominence through social media and anti-corruption activism, appealing to rural and working-class voters.
Paz’s appeal is strong among rural and older voters, especially those disillusioned with MAS’s economic policies and inflation.
Paz’s promise to avoid IMF bailouts and promote gradual, stable reforms has drawn both support and criticism for lacking fiscal clarity.
The U.S. State Department congratulated Paz and expressed a desire to restore economic stability and strengthen security ties with Bolivia, marking a shift from past tensions.
The election reflects deep class and regional divisions, with Paz winning in rural and Indigenous areas and Quiroga in wealthier eastern regions.
Paz’s campaign slogan 'capitalism for all' resonated with entrepreneurs who benefited from Morales’ natural gas boom but were frustrated by later taxation and regulation.

namedEntities.name: Rodrigo Paz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Centrist senator and elected president of Bolivia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the article, winning the presidential election and marking a political shift in Bolivia after 20 years of MAS rule.

namedEntities.name: Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former right-wing president and political opponent of Rodrigo Paz
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was the main rival in the runoff election, representing a radical shift away from MAS-style social protections toward IMF-style economic reforms.

namedEntities.name: Movement Toward Socialism (MAS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Dominant political party in Bolivia for nearly two decades, led by Evo Morales
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The party’s long rule and economic policies are the backdrop for the current political upheaval and voter disillusionment.

namedEntities.name: Edman Lara
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former police officer and running mate of Rodrigo Paz
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He brought attention to anti-corruption activism and resonated with rural and working-class voters, significantly influencing the campaign.

namedEntities.name: U.S. State Department
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. government agency responsible for foreign relations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It congratulated the new Bolivian president and expressed interest in rebuilding economic and security ties with Bolivia after years of tension.

namedEntities.name: International Monetary Fund (IMF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Global financial institution that offers economic bailouts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Quiroga advocated a bailout approach, which drew skepticism from voters; Paz pledged to avoid the IMF, signaling a major policy divergence.

namedEntities.name: Evo Morales
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Founder of MAS and Bolivia’s first Indigenous president
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His legacy defines the economic and political model that Paz seeks to replace, setting the context for the current transformation.

namedEntities.name: La Paz
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where the election results were declared and where protests and celebrations took place, highlighting the political and social energy of the nation.

namedEntities.name: Cochabamba
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Region in western Bolivia known for coca production
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key region where Paz’s party won, indicating a shift among Indigenous populations from MAS support to centrist appeal.

namedEntities.name: Santa Cruz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Wealthier agricultural region in eastern Bolivia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A region that supported Quiroga, showing class-based political divisions in the country.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator and political outsider, has won Bolivia’s presidential election with 54.5% of the vote, defeating former president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga. This marks the end of 20 years of MAS rule and signals a major political and economic shift. Paz, running with ex-police officer Edman Lara, appeals to rural and working-class voters frustrated by inflation, fuel shortages, and economic mismanagement. His plan to dismantle Bolivia’s fixed exchange rate, end fuel subsidies, and reduce public spending represents a sharp departure from the MAS economic model. Despite promising gradual reforms to avoid recession, critics question the fiscal feasibility of his approach. The U.S. State Department congratulated Paz and expressed interest in restoring economic stability and bilateral relations, marking a reversal from past tensions. The election reflects deep class and regional divides, with Paz winning in rural and Indigenous areas and Quiroga in wealthier eastern zones. Paz’s victory sets Bolivia on a path of economic uncertainty and potential transformation, with his inauguration scheduled for November 8.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivian Presidential Election, Ending 20 Years of MAS Rule
